messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On the Complexity of Identifying Strongly Regular Graphs

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper, we show that Graph Isomorphism (GI) is not AC0superscriptAC0\textsf{AC}^{0}-reducible to several problems, including the Latin Square Isotopy problem, isomorphism testing of several families of Steiner designs, and isomorphism testing of conference graphs. As a corollary, we obtain that GI is not AC0superscriptAC0\textsf{AC}^{0}-reducible to isomorphism testing of Latin square graphs and strongly regular graphs arising from special cases of Steiner 222-designs. We accomplish this by showing that the generator-enumeration technique for each of these problems can be implemented in Œ≤2‚ÄãFOLLsubscriptùõΩ2FOLL\beta_{2}\textsf{FOLL}, which cannot compute Parity (Chattopadhyay, Tor√°n, & Wagner, ACM Trans. Comp. Theory, 2013).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Computational Complexity: A Modern Approach",
        "Graph isomorphism is in SPP",
        "Quasigroups. I",
        "On the complexity of canonical labeling of strongly regular graphs",
        "On the order of uniprimitive permutation groups",
        "On the automorphism groups of strongly regular graphs I",
        "Graph isomorphism in quasipolynomial time [extended abstract]",
        "Construction of finite groups",
        "A millennium project: Constructing small groups",
        "Superpolynomial circuits, almost sparse oracles and the exponential hierarchy",
        "Computational complexity and the classification of finite simple groups",
        "On the complexity of some problems on groups input as multiplication tables",
        "Canonical labeling of graphs",
        "Strongly regular graphs, partial geometries and partially balanced designs",
        "Finite nets. II. Uniqueness and imbedding",
        "Quasipolynomial-time canonical form for Steiner designs",
        "Concerning the complexity of deciding isomorphism of block designs",
        "An optimal lower bound on the number of variables for graph identification",
        "An efficient algorithm for graph isomorphism",
        "Automorphism group computation and isomorphism testing in finite groups",
        "On cyclic Steiner 2-designs",
        "An analysis technique for Steiner triple systems",
        "Multi-stage design for quasipolynomial-time isomorphism testing of steiner 2-systems",
        "Graph isomorphism is not AC0superscriptAC0\\rm AC^{0}-reducible to group isomorphism",
        "Constructing automorphism groups of pùëùp-groups",
        "Testing graph isomorphism in parallel by playing a game",
        "Computational complexity of reconstruction and isomorphism testing for designs and line graphs",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Power and Limits of the Weisfeiler‚ÄìLeman Algorithm",
        "Graph isomorphism is low for PP",
        "On the structure of polynomial time reducibility",
        "On the group and color isomorphism problems",
        "On the ratio of optimal integral and fractional covers",
        "Isomorphism of graphs of bounded valence can be tested in polynomial time",
        "A note on the graph isomorphism counting problem",
        "On the nlog‚Å°nsuperscriptùëõùëõn^{\\log n} isomorphism technique (a preliminary report)",
        "Mutually orthogonal latin squares and self-complementary designs",
        "Strongly regular graphs with smallest eigenvalue ‚àímùëö-m",
        "An exponential lower bound for individualization-refinement algorithms for graph isomorphism",
        "On tùë°t-designs",
        "Bidirectional collision detection and faster deterministic isomorphism testing",
        "Graph isomorphism is in the low hierarchy",
        "A fast backtracking algorithm to test directed graphs for isomorphism using distance matrices",
        "Computational complexity of k-block conjugacy",
        "Algebraic methods in the theory of lower bounds for boolean circuit complexity",
        "Faster Isomorphism Testing of Strongly Regular Graphs",
        "A simple group of order 448,345,497,600448345497600448,345,497,600",
        "Towards Understanding Satisfiability, Group Isomorphism and Their Connections",
        "On the hardness of graph isomorphism",
        "Introduction to Circuit Complexity - A Uniform Approach",
        "The threshold for subgroup profiles to agree is logarithmic",
        "Nondeterministic circuits, space complexity and quasigroups",
        "Graph isomorphism problem",
        "Complexity zoo"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On the Complexity of Identifying Strongly Regular Graphs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
